# Welcome to MS Open Tech Cocos2d-x pages
Find here dedicated ressources and content to Cocos2d-x on Windows
MS Open Tech is contributing to Cocos2d-x, the last contribution and branches are:
V2.2.5 Universal App
V3.3   Universal App

*last update Dec 19th 2014

# Installing Cocos2d-x on Windows

###Steps to get the v3.3 Universal App version
1.	git clone https://github.com/MSOpenTech/cocos2d-x.git
2.	cd cocos2d-x
3.	git checkout v3-stable
4.	git submodule update --init
5.	download-deps.py
6.	setup.py (then restart your console to update settings)

Create your first project:
1.	cocos new MyGame -p com.bar.foo -l cpp -d projects
1.	open MyGame.sln in cocos2d-x\projects\MyGame\proj-win8.1-universal\

### Steps to get the v2.2.5 Universal App version
1.	git clone https://github.com/MSOpenTech/cocos2d-x.git
2.	cd cocos2d-x
3.	git checkout v2-universal
4.	git submodule update --init
5.	download-deps.py 

Create your first project in v2.2.5:
1.	cd tools\project-creator
1.	create_project.py -project MyGame -package com.foo.bar -language cpp
1.	open MyGame.sln in cocos2d-x\projects\MyGame\proj-win8.1-universal\ 


**Warning**:
December 16th 2014, it appears that a recent Windows Update (KB2976978) breaks the Windows App Certification (WACK) Test for the Windows Store App in the Cocos2d-x v3.3 Universal App. The update causes the Supported API test to fail with a lot of errors. 
Work Around:
* Go to Control Panel â€“ Program and Features 
* Click on View Installed Updates 
* Uninstall update KB2976978 
* The Windows Store app now passes the Supported API test 

**Tips & Tricks**
For the v3 the images/sprites folder changed. 
All your graphical resources have to be in the **MyGame\Resources** folder.
These will be copied during the build phase in MyGame\proj.win8.1-universal\Debug\MyGame.Windows\AppX\Assets\Resources (for the Windows version) If something wrong happen, just verify that your resources are in this folder (Appx\Assets\Resources) if not just copy paste their in it 

We recommend using Visual Studio 2013 Community edition (http://www.visualstudio.com/en-us/news/vs2013-community-vs.aspx)
